results.title: The Innocents [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jack Clayton, Achilles Productions, Jack Clayton Productions and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A dark but brilliantly realised adaptation of Henry James’ gothic horror tale ‘Turn of the Screw’. A 19th century British governess (Deborah Kerr) arrives at a bleak mansion to take care of the wealthy household’s two children. Gradually, she begins to believe that there is a malevolent force in the children despite their beatific appearance. While Henry James’ novel leaves little doubt that they have been possessed by the demonic souls of the previous governess and her valet lover, who had died on the estate after an illicit sadomasochistic relationship, the film entertains the possibility that the supernatural events experienced by the governess are merely the product of her vivid imagination. Clayton cleverly uses startling imagery and nerve-bending sound to terrify the audience. Through its use of decor and lighting, and the impressive performances of Kerr and Michael Redgrave as the uncle, the film effectively conveys a claustrophobic sense of repressed hysteria. Cast also includes Megs Jenkins, Pamela Franklin, Martin Stephens and Peter Wyngarde. Also on VHS NTSC [315944].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Clayton, Achilles Productions, Jack Clayton Productions and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation

results.title: The Industrial city
results.creator_credit: Hermann D. Tauchert and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Uses a case study of the industrial city of Detroit in order to present a view of the function of the industrial community in modern American society. Emphasises the fact that the future of a city depends on the education, training and ability of the people. Also discusses the automobile industry where 10,000 cars are produced per day at this time. Touches on the problems of traffic congestion, pollution, poverty and clime.

results.title: The Indian in the cupboard
results.creator_credit: Frank Oz, Frank Marshall, Jane Startz, Kathleen Kennedy, Kennedy/Marshall Company and Scholastic Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Lynne Reid Banks, ‘The Indian in the cupboard’ is a heartwarming adventure about nine year old Omri who magically brings his three-inch toy Indian Little Bear to life. Some of the scenes may not be suitable for very young children however the amazing adventures of these two friends is sure to delight.

results.title: The Immortal battalion = The Way ahead
results.creator_credit: Carol Reed, John Sutro, Norman Walker, G C F and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: Beginning as a British Army training film called “The New lot”, this film was then expanded into a feature length film written by Eric Ambler and Peter Ustinov, entitled “The Way ahead” for its British audience and re-edited into a slightly shorter film entitled “The Immortal battalion” for an American audience. Its basic concept is as a recruiting and training film for the British Army mixing training and combat footage with filmed sequences. The storyline is about a bunch of raw recruits from a variety of backgrounds who are finally welded into a unified and disciplined regimental unit ready for battle. Stars David Niven, Stanley Holloway, Peter Ustinov, Trevor Howard.

results.title: The Image makers
results.creator_credit: Albert Kish, Adam Symansky, Peter Katadotis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A documentary about the National Film Board of Canada made to commemorate the Board’s 40th anniversary in 1979. It is a montage representing the work of over 400 people whose dedicated efforts have garnered over 1800 international awards for the Board. Sometimes majestic, sometimes whimsical, the film is a revue of a nation’s sights and sounds.

results.title: The Human body: the making of the TV series [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Liesel Evans, BBC and Learning Channel
results.brief_description: The final episode in “The Human body” series takes the viewer on a fascinating journey behind how the series was created and how they were able to create the impressive special effects. Presented by Robert Winston.

results.title: The Human body: how it works
results.brief_description: Designed for primary students in Years 5 and 6, this is an introduction to the component parts of the human body; how these parts interact and are interdependent. Short segments explain the skeleton, muscles, nerves, brain, blood, heart, digestive system, waste disposal and the lungs. A Teacher’s Guide suggests follow-up activities and discussion questions for use in the classroom.

results.title: The Human animal: a personal view of the human species. - Part 1. (X)
results.creator_credit: Clive Bromhall, John MacNish, Mike Beynon and BBC
results.brief_description: Desmond Morris attempts to illustrate how the many ways human beings behave across cultures have their roots in our “animal” past. The three programs are: “The Language of the body” which examines the origins of our body language and how body language signals vary across cultures. “The Hunting ape” examines how our primeval hunting habits have been mainfested in activities such as sport and mob behaviour. “The Human zoo” looks at how urban humans deal with their tribalistic instincts. This episode contains some full frontal nudity.

results.title: The House of exorcism = Lisa and the devil
results.creator_credit: Mario Bava, Mickey Lion and Leone International Film
results.brief_description: Originally filmed as ‘Lisa and the Devil’, Mario Bava’s creepy and atmospheric chiller was re-cut for the American market, with a demonic possession sub-plot (directed by Mickey Lion), added to capitalise on the success of ‘The Exorcist’. As it stands now this rather disjointed film stars Elke Sommers as Lisa, a woman holidaying in an unspecified European city. Along her travels she begins to notice a strange man (Telly Savalas, sporting his trademark chuppa-chup) following her, who carries around with him a creepy life like mannequin who may or may not be Satan. Lisa suddenly begins to convulse and is rushed off to hospital. Her condition is soon diagnosed as demonic possession (vomiting, profanity, etc.) and a priest (Robert Alda) is brought in to help. These scenes are intercut with strange dream-like sequences of Lisa in an unspecified gothic mansion, where a mentally disturbed man (Alessio Orano) lives with his blind mother and their butler (Savalas again), who may or may not be Satan. Also known as: ‘La casa dell’esorcismo’, ‘Lisa and the Devil’, ‘The devil in the house of exorcism’, and ‘The devil and the dead’. Cast also includes Alida Valli and Sylva Koscina.

results.title: The Icicle thief
results.creator_credit: Maurizio Nichetti, Aries Film and Bambu
results.brief_description: In his ingenious comedy, Nichetti has takena wide-eyed look at Italian cinema, past and present, and has staggered back from the vision, his mind brimming with invention. On one hand, there’s Italy’s hallowed neo-realist past; grainy, black-and-white postwar images full of stubbled, unemployed fathers, sacrficial mothers and brave bustling priests. On the other, there are the television shows that “present” these films: a wasteland of lofty critics, only too willing to interpret a director’s deepest motives and intentions- even to the director himself. Nichetti has created a hilarious movie that mixes the world of cinema and television into a comic masterpiece.
